content.description: This is the problem a lot of people send when they think they're doing EZ Cheese. It starts the same as  the classic cheese on the awesome jug, but immediately moves left into the gaston before moving to the lip and topping out. A little bit easier, a little less classic.
content.location: From Gandalf's Lair cross stream towards Yosemite Boulder. This climb is on your left 30ft from the Buttermilk Boulder.

content.description: Stand start on the good holds used for "E-Z Cheese" and "Swiss Cheese". Find a good foot and dyno up and left to the lip of the boulder before topping out. Pretty big move, but rocking onto the foot gets you there.
content.location: Juggy holds of E-Z and Swiss.

content.description: A nice little face climb with the crux coming at the top.  Sit start a few feet left of the arete with a good rail.  Pull up right either to the arete or the large crimp.  Match the crimp then go left to a small crimp and either hit a sloper on the arete or the lip before topping out.
content.location: Across the stream from the Zoo is an alcove formed by the Kissing Cousins boulders.  This climbs the face and arete on the right side of the alcove.

content.description: Rising above the stream, this obvious shallow dihedral and the crux sit start is unfortunately only climbable when the water level is low.  When this is climbable, climb it!  Sit start in the streambed below the dihedral with some interesting pockets and power up to a sloper.  Make a few more moves to get yourself into the corner and follow the better holds straight to the top.
content.location: On the upstream side of the Streambed Boulders, this problem actually starts in the stream.  Getting off the boulder is easy.

content.description:
While most people simply walk past this slightly overhanging arete, it deserves more love than it gets.  The movement is fun, the foot beta has a techy nature to it, and there are numerous ways to unlock the sequence.  Sit start with your right hand pinching the arete with the help of a good thumbcatch.  For your left hand you can either use the bad sloper or the small razor blade.  Pull off the ground and stand up into the left hand undercling.  Slap up the arete, work your feet, and then choose your adventure... 

  Method 1 - Dyno to a crimp a few inches below the lip and then topout on jugs. 

  Method 2 - Stick a small sloper with your left hand and bump your right up to the good rail.  Topout on jugs. 

  Method 3 - Stay tight and move your left hand into a tiny sidepull, then bump your right to the good rail.  Topout on jugs. 

  Maybe it's the rock sticking out of the ground that annoys people.  It's actually not in the way.
content.location: On the other side of the tree from the problem EZ Cheese.  There is usually chalk on the starting sloper/crimp.

content.description: A short slab climb that is also kind of spooky.  Starting right of the tree on a rock platform above the stream, step onto the wall using the good foothold.  Notice the lack of holds.  Smear straight up for a couple of moves until you can reach the good holds (the only holds), then make easier moves to the top.
content.protection: Pads & spotter - even better, don't fall.
content.location: On the upstream side of the boulder, left of The Riverbed.  Start on the boulder ledge immediately right of the tree.

content.description: A quick beginner problem.  Stand start and pull on to the low angle face to the right of the arete and climb straight up on good holds.
content.location: Across the stream from the Zoo, this problem climbs the slabby face to the right of Seinfeld.

content.description: Despite it's scruffy appearance, all the necessary holds are clean and it's more fun than it looks.  Stand start to the right of the arete with a left hand on the arete and your right on a bad crimp.  Pull up and pop to the sloper (or use an intermediate crimp) before pressing it out to finish up.  Maybe a little sandbagged.
content.location: Across the stream from the Zoo, this problem climbs the slightly scruffy face on the left side of the alcove.

content.description: This is one of my all time favorite routes. Start to the left of E-Z Cheese, traverse into the chimney created by the two boulders using the jugs on the left side of the chimney. The ground gets lower as you move out then becomes a hole straight through the boulders, if you get scared remember the boulder behind you and you can get a no-hands knee bar between the two boulders at any point on the traverse. Finnish at the end of the chimney where you come out on the other side of the stream by Bulletproof.
content.protection: Pad at the start or end
content.location: Start to the left of E-Z Cheese, enter the Obvious Chimney, between two boulders.

content.description: Sit down in the small corridor with your hands in the wide crack.  Climb the right arete formed by the crack up to better holds before making a big move to the top arete.  Commit to a spooky topout over a boulder and try not to blow it.
content.location: Across the stream from the Zoo (or just downhill from the Illmob), this problem climbs the obvious crack on the left side of the alcove.

content.description:
The classic line at the grade in Boulder Natural. Stand start on a huge jug, set your feet and fire up and left to the cool triangular pinch. Grab a right crimp and bump to the jug on the lip up and right. Topout next to the tree.   Landing is a bit painful so don't botch the dyno/deadpoint/topout. 

  Sit start goes at V3. 

  If you used the gaston on the left, see Swiss Cheese
content.protection: Pads to fill the void in the landing, spotter would be nice too.
content.location: From Gandalf's Lair cross stream towards Yosemite Boulder. This climb is on your left 30ft from Buttermilk Boulder.

content.description:
Start standing in the center of the tall slab, with the left hand on a gaston crimp and the right wherever. Head straight up the slab utilizing a shallow dish/pocket and good footwork to reach the juggy rail below the lip. Follow the rail up and left, topping out at the apex of the boulder. 

  I'm sure this climb has been done before. I feel like's it a purer and better option than 'North Slab', which is located to the left. And while it may be taller, the landing zone is much better.  

  Note that this problem can only be climbed when the stream bed is dry enough.
content.protection: A couple of pads are ideal, especially if this is at or near your limit.
content.location: Located in between 'The Riverbed' and 'North Slab', on the same boulder as 'Provia' and 'EZ Cheese'.

content.description: This line goes straight up the big face next to Provia via good crimps. GrabÂ the juggy lip and mantle. Definitely worth doing.
content.location: When looking at Provia, to the right of it there is a dihedral, and to the right of that is the slab where this climb is situated.

content.description: Sit start in the hole with large feet, right hand on a large side pull and left on a crimp. Climb up and left on jugs to the aerie then top out.
content.location: Left of Feel the Pull on the Kissing Cousins Boulders. On the uphill side.

content.description: The Streambed Boulders are a collection of four boulders that practically sit in the stream.  Imagine that.  The two closest to the Illmob Boulder are called the Kissing Cousins, while the stream actually runs beneath the other two.  Most of the problems here have been left out of the guidebook, but nearly all of them are worthwhile.  Classics include EZ Cheese, the Riverbed, and Seinfeld, but for something more difficult, give Provia a try.
